emergencies.title: Heart Attack
emergencies.description: A heart attack occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked, causing damage to heart muscle.
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Help the person stay calm and seated.
Administer aspirin (if not allergic) to thin the blood.
Perform CPR if the person becomes unconscious and stops breathing.
Keep the environment quiet and stress-free.
donts: Do not leave the person alone.
Avoid giving food or drink unless instructed.
Do not delay seeking medical help, even if symptoms seem mild.
Avoid physical exertion or stressful activities.
Do not administer any medication other than aspirin.

questions.text: On a scale of 1 to 10, how severe is the chest pain?
Has the person lost consciousness at any point?
How would you describe the person's breathing?
Does the person have a known history of heart disease?
Is the person allergic to aspirin?

emergencies.title: Stroke
emergencies.description: A stroke occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen.
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Note the time when symptoms started.
Keep the person safe and comfortable.
Turn the person on their side if unconscious to prevent choking.
Stay with the person and provide reassurance.
donts: Do not give food, drink, or medication unless instructed.
Avoid moving the person unless necessary.
Do not ignore symptoms like sudden weakness or confusion.
Avoid delaying medical attention, even if symptoms improve temporarily.
Do not perform CPR unless breathing stops.

questions.text: Ask the person to smile. Is there any facial drooping?
Ask the person to raise both arms. Does one arm drift downward?
Ask the person to repeat a simple sentence. Is their speech slurred or difficult to understand?
How long ago did the symptoms start?
Has the person experienced sudden vision changes?

emergencies.title: Severe Bleeding
emergencies.description: Severe bleeding can be life-threatening and requires immediate intervention to prevent shock.
dos: Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
Elevate the injured area above the heart.
Call emergency services immediately.
Use gloves or other barriers to prevent infection.
Monitor for signs of shock.
donts: Do not remove embedded objects.
Avoid using unclean materials.
Do not wash severe wounds with water.
Avoid tourniquets unless trained.
Do not delay seeking medical help.

questions.text: Is the bleeding controlled with direct pressure?
Approximately how much blood has been lost?
Is the person showing signs of shock (pale skin, rapid breathing, dizziness)?
Where is the bleeding located?
Is an object embedded in the wound?

emergencies.title: Unconscious Person
emergencies.description: An unconscious person is unable to respond to stimuli and requires immediate assessment and emergency care.
dos: Check for breathing and pulse; begin CPR if necessary.
Place the person in the recovery position if breathing.
Call emergency services immediately.
Ensure the airway is clear.
Stay with the person until help arrives.
donts: Do not shake or slap the person.
Avoid giving food, drink, or medication.
Do not move the person unless in danger.
Avoid leaving them unattended.
Do not ignore breathing difficulty or irregular pulse.

questions.text: Is the person breathing?
Do you feel a pulse?
Do you know the possible cause of unconsciousness?
Did you witness seizure activity before they became unconscious?
Does the person respond to any stimuli (e.g., shouting, gentle shaking)?

emergencies.title: Chest Pain
emergencies.description: Chest pain may indicate a heart problem or other serious condition and should never be ignored.
dos: Call emergency services immediately if pain persists or worsens.
Help the person sit comfortably and stay calm.
Administer aspirin if advised and no allergies exist.
Monitor vital signs.
Encourage slow, steady breathing.
donts: Do not ignore chest pain.
Avoid exertion or stress.
Do not administer medications without advice.
Avoid assuming chest pain is non-serious.
Do not delay calling for help if symptoms worsen.

questions.text: How would you describe the pain?
Does the pain radiate to other areas?
Are there any associated symptoms (sweating, nausea, shortness of breath)?
On a scale of 1 to 10, how severe is the pain?
Does the person have known heart problems?

emergencies.title: Breathing Difficulty
emergencies.description: Difficulty breathing can be a symptom of various conditions, from anxiety to serious heart or lung issues.
dos: Help the person sit upright.
Administer prescribed inhalers.
Call emergency services if breathing worsens.
Encourage slow breaths.
Monitor for cyanosis.
donts: Do not lie the person flat.
Avoid panicking.
Do not administer unprescribed medications.
Avoid delaying medical attention for severe symptoms.
Do not leave the person unattended.

questions.text: How severe is the breathing difficulty?
Is the person wheezing?
Does the person have asthma, COPD, or other respiratory issues?
Are the lips or fingernails bluish?
What could have triggered this breathing?

emergencies.title: Allergic Reaction
emergencies.description: An allergic reaction is the body's immune response to a foreign substance. Severe reactions can be life-threatening.
dos: Administer an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if available.
Call emergency services for severe symptoms.
Keep the person seated and calm.
Remove exposure to allergens.
Monitor vital signs.
donts: Do not wait for symptoms to worsen.
Avoid giving food or drink.
Do not assume mild reactions will stay mild.
Avoid delaying epinephrine administration.
Do not leave the person alone.

questions.text: What is the person allergic to?
Has an EpiPen been administered?
Is the person having difficulty breathing or swallowing?
Is there swelling of the face, lips, or throat?
Describe the hives

emergencies.title: Broken Bone
emergencies.description: A broken bone is a disruption in the continuity of bone tissue, usually caused by high force impact or stress.
dos: Immobilize the affected area.
Apply ice packs (wrapped in cloth).
Seek medical attention.
Keep the injured limb elevated.
Provide reassurance.
donts: Do not attempt to straighten the bone.
Avoid applying pressure directly to open fractures.
Do not use unclean materials for splints.
Avoid delaying treatment.
Do not move unnecessarily.

questions.text: Is there obvious deformity in the injured area?
Is the bone protruding through the skin?
On a scale of 1 to 10, how severe is the pain?
How much can the person move?
Is there any numbness or tingling in the injured limb?

emergencies.title: Burns
emergencies.description: Burns are tissue damage caused by heat, chemicals, electricity, radiation, or friction.
dos: Cool the burn with cool running water for 10–20 minutes.
Cover with a sterile, non-stick dressing.
Remove jewelry/clothing near the burn (if not stuck to the skin).
Elevate burned limbs to reduce swelling.
Seek medical care for burns larger than the palm or on sensitive areas.
donts: Do not apply ice, butter, or ointments.
Avoid breaking blisters.
Do not remove clothing stuck to the burn.
Avoid using adhesive bandages directly on the burn.
Do not ignore signs of infection (redness, pus).

questions.text: What caused the burn?
What is the depth of the burn?
Estimate the percentage of body surface area burned.
What part of the body is burned?
Is there evidence of inhalation injury (soot around nose/mouth, hoarseness)?

emergencies.title: Choking
emergencies.description: Choking occurs when an object becomes lodged in the throat or windpipe, blocking airflow.
dos: Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) if the person cannot cough, speak, or breathe.
Call emergency services if the obstruction persists.
Encourage coughing if partially choking.
Check the mouth for visible obstructions.
Stay with the person until medical help arrives.
donts: Do not slap the person's back while upright.
Avoid blind finger sweeps in the mouth.
Do not ignore persistent coughing or wheezing.
Avoid giving water or food until the airway is clear.
Do not delay emergency care for prolonged choking.

questions.text: How would you characterize the airway obstruction?
Is the person conscious?
What do you think the person was choking on?
Are there signs of cyanosis (blue lips/nails)?
Have abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) been attempted?

emergencies.title: Poisoning
emergencies.description: Poisoning occurs when a harmful substance is ingested, inhaled, injected, or absorbed through the skin.
dos: Call emergency services or poison control immediately.
Identify the substance ingested.
Keep the person upright if conscious.
Follow instructions from medical professionals.
Monitor breathing and pulse.
donts: Do not induce vomiting unless instructed.
Avoid giving food/drink without guidance.
Do not ignore symptoms like seizures or unconsciousness.
Avoid handling toxic substances without gloves.
Do not wait for symptoms before seeking help.

questions.text: What substance was ingested?
How much of the substance was ingested/inhaled?
How long ago was the substance ingested? (Minutes)
What symptoms is the person experiencing?
Are there any empty pill bottles or chemical containers nearby?
